title: How to Spatchcock a Turkey

steps.headline: Get a pair of carbon steel kitchen or poultry shears.
steps.description: Turkey bones are pretty tough to cut through, so spatchcocking requires a sharp and effective tool. Look for high-quality shears made of carbon steel, which is a stronger material than simple stainless steel. The shears should also have tiny serrations that provide better grip as you cut through food. You can also use a sharp knife, but shears give you more control over your cutting. This makes the process safer.

steps.headline: Cut just to the left and right of the backbone.
steps.description: Place the turkey on a stable surface with the drumsticks facing up and the breasts facing down. Locate the backbone in the middle of the bird. There should be a hole directly above the drumsticks, which might contain a bag full of giblets. Remove the bag and position your shears at the bottom of the backbone (right at the top of the hole) to cut it out. It might take some patience and elbow grease to make these two cuts. Keep at it and take a break if you need one. Once you’ve removed the backbone, put it aside with the giblets to make turkey stock for your gravy.

steps.headline: Open up the bird to expose the keel bone.
steps.description: Spread the turkey apart slightly and look down into the center of the opened-up bird. At the bottom of the bird, you’ll see the keel bone, which extends downward from the breastbone. The keel bone is essentially a mirror image of the backbone, running vertically from the top to the bottom of the bird.

steps.headline: Slide the tip of a sharp knife along the length of the keel bone.
steps.description: This will make it easier to crack the bone and flatten the turkey. You don’t need to cut the bird in half or make a deep cut. Just score the bone by applying a healthy amount of even, steady pressure as you move the knife.

steps.headline: Turn the turkey over and press on it until you hear a crack.
steps.description: Pick up the bird with both hands and flip the bird so the the opened-up side is face down on your kitchen surface. Place your hands on the breasts and push. You should hear a cracking sound as the bird flattens out. Once the bottom of the bird is flush with your kitchen surface, stop pressing.

steps.headline: Tuck the wingtips under the breasts to prepare for roasting.
steps.description: The wingtips should be resting on the two breasts. Gently bend them out and over the tops of the breasts. Then, bend them inwards again, positioning the tips under the front of the bird. This will allow the the wings to cook through completely.

steps.headline: Brine your turkey if you want to add extra flavor.
steps.description: Wash the inside and outside of your turkey in cold water before you brine it. Then make a brining solution and soak your spatchcocked bird in the liquid overnight. Brining may add a bit of extra flavor and moisture to your turkey, but it’s also messy and time-consuming. Check that the pot you plan to use to soak your turkey fits in your fridge before you start the brining process. A good recipe for brining solution should include vegetable broth or water, salt, and an assortment of herbs. If you choose a roasting recipe that calls for lots of herbs and basting, you probably don’t need to brine.

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 450 °F (232 °C) for a traditional roast turkey.
steps.description: Spatchcocking allows you to cook your turkey at a higher temperature than you normally would. The total cook time should be about an hour and a half. Give the oven about 5 to 10 minutes to heat up completely. You can also grill your turkey if you’d like.

steps.headline: Pat your turkey’s skin dry and rub it with butter and herbs.
steps.description: Wash the inside and outside of the bird with cold water. Then, use paper towels to pat it completely dry. Next, rub either melted butter or olive oil over the entire surface of the skin. Season the bird with sea salt, pepper, rosemary, thyme, and sage. Follow your recipe for precise measurements, but expect to use about ⁄2 cup (120 ml) of oil or butter and a tablespoon (14.8 mL) of each of the herbs for the rub. You should also rinse and pat dry your brined turkey. This will prevent it from being overly salty.

steps.headline: Place your turkey on vegetables in a sheet pan.
steps.description: Arrange several whole celery stalks, quartered onions, peeled and halved carrots, halved garlic cloves, and sprigs of rosemary and thyme in the bottom of the pan. They should create a layer for the bird to rest on. After you’ve placed the bird on top of the veggies and herbs, add ⁄2 cup (120 ml) water to the sheet pan. Alternatively, you can use a wire rack to lift the bird off the bottom of the pan. The vegetables and herbs will give your turkey and gravy more flavor, however. Follow your recipe for specific instructions on which vegetables (and how many) to place in your pan.

steps.headline: Baste every 20 to 30 minutes.
steps.description: Roast the bird for 30 minutes at 450 °F (232 °C). While it’s cooking, prepare a basting liquid of melted butter or oil. After the half hour is up, use a brush to cover the skin in the liquid. You can also use a bulb baster to suck up some of the juices in the pan and drip those over the turkey’s skin. After the first baste, continue to baste every 20 minutes until your bird is done.

steps.headline: Reduce the heat to 350 °F (177 °C) and cook for another hour.
steps.description: Your bird still has a while to go in the oven, but it’s time to turn down the heat. Continue basting every 20 minutes. Use a meat thermometer to keep track of the temperature of the bird. Insert it into the thickest part of the thigh (which is on the side of the bird, attached to the drumsticks). Once the thermometer reads 165 °F (74 °C), it’s time to take the bird out of the oven! This cook time is for a 12 to 14 pound (5.4-6.3 kg) turkey. Make adjustments if you’re cooking a smaller or larger bird by continuously checking the thermometer and removing the turkey from the oven as soon as it hits 165 °F (74 °C).

steps.headline: Keep your turkey under a tent of foil for several minutes.
steps.description: Once you’ve removed the turkey from the oven, transfer it to a cutting board and place the foil tent over it. Allowing the turkey to rest locks the flavor and juiciness into the meat. Let smaller birds rest for at least 20 minutes and larger birds for up to 40 minutes.

steps.headline: Use a sharp carving knife.
steps.description: Choose a knife that’s designed especially for carving meat. This will make it easier to make the cuts, and it’ll actually help you avoid injury.

steps.headline: Remove both legs by slicing across where the thigh meets the body.
steps.description: Cut right through the thigh bones. You may need to exert some pressure to make these cuts.

steps.headline: Cut through the leg joints to remove the drumsticks.
steps.description: You can now separate the drumsticks from the thighs. Find the leg joints by wiggling the drumsticks back and forth. Make decisive cuts right through the joints.

steps.headline: Remove the wings from the top of the turkey.
steps.description: Lift the wings from their position at the tops of the breasts and wiggle them to find the ball joints. Work your knife through these joints one at a time. You can either leave the wings whole or make them into smaller, more manageable portions. To cut them up, slice through the middle joints of the wings.

steps.headline: Cut away the breast meat to make two complete halves.
steps.description: Put your hand on top of one breast to grip it firmly. Using your other hand, make a cut from the top to the bottom of the bird. This cut should follow the contour of the keel bone. Work your knife underneath the breast so you can slowly lift it away from the bird in one piece. Repeat to remove the other breast.

steps.headline: Make several slices through each of the breasts.
steps.description: Angle your knife so you can make your cuts at a slant, giving you better slices. Once you’ve cut both breasts, place these perfectly-cut servings on a warm platter! Warm your platter by putting it in the oven on its lowest setting, which is usually 150 °F (66 °C), for about 5 minutes.

steps.headline: Remove the hip and thigh bones from the thighs.
steps.description: Flip over the thighs so the bones are exposed (the skin side should be face down). Lift the flat hip bones on the sides of the thighs and move them back and forth until you can pry them off the bird. Next, cut along both sides of the thigh bones with your knife so that you can remove the bones from the meat. Slice through this boneless thigh meat to give your guests easy-to-eat portions. You can save all of these bones, along with the entire turkey carcass, to make soup.

steps.headline: Arrange the different meat pieces on your platter.
steps.description: Place the slices of breast meat on one side of the platter and the sliced-up thigh meat on the other. This will allow your guests to easily choose between white and dark meat. Then, lay the wings on the outer edges of the platter. Finally, place the two drumsticks in the middle of the platter, facing in opposite directions. If necessary, you can layer the different types of meat on top of each other a bit to make them all fit on the platter. To make your platter extra spectacular, put down a bed of crisp leafy greens before you lay down the meat. Once your meat is added, create a fall-themed border of ruby-red apples, sprigs of rosemary, and mini-pumpkins.
